issue.title: packaged_task::operator= should abandon its shared state

discussion.p: The `packaged_task` move assignment operator is specified to release the previous shared state. This means it releases ownership, but does not make the shared state ready. Any future that shares ownership of the shared state will never receive a result, because the provider is gone. This means that any thread that waits on the future will block forever.
There is a note on `packaged_task::reset()` which claims that assignment abandons the state, which is not supported by any normative wording:

blockquote.p: -26- Effects: As if `*this = packaged_task(std::move(f))`, where `f` is the task stored in `*this`.
[Note 2:â€‚This constructs a new shared state for `*this`. The old state is abandoned (). — end note]

discussion.p: Presumably, the intended behaviour of assignment was to abandon the shared state, i.e. make it ready with a `broken_promise` error, and then release it. That is what the `std::promise` move assignment does (see p9). Both libstdc++ and libc++ abandon the state, despite what the standard says.
